name: Online Co-host
motto: As a Co-host, you support the Online Host.

text: You as will keep an eye on the waiting room and admit people inside
The online host is needed for those times when a meeting has to be hosted online.
The online host is responsible for making sure that the meeting can run smoothly from a technical perspective but also from a security perspective.

textbox.heading: Meeting - onboarding presentation
text: If the meeting happens on the 1st or 5th Saturday of a month, show a presentation that explains the technical details. (Because new guests are attending and don't know how it works)
If the meeting is on the 3rd Saturday of a month, make the presentation short and only cover the meeting rules, and speaker line up.
Download the Template for Zoom meetings from the side box.
Also make sure to prepare the feedback form and share it before and during the meeting with attendees.

Congratulations! This is an opportunity for you to showcase your presentation skills. Although you are not making a speech, you are going to be on stage talking for a good amount of time acting as the host and making introductions.

orderedInstructions.mainLine: Come up with a meeting theme. It can be anything, a colour "Purple" or a theme like "Kindness" or a quote for example "An apple a day keeps the doctor away". It is important to choose a theme that you can work with and incorporate into the morning. Most importantly, have fun with it!

Once you come up with the theme, update the meeting schedule in EasySpeak to add the theme. This should be done at least one week, preferably two, in advance. This gives members something to look forward to, and if possible, although not mandatory, it might give inspiration to the speakers in choosing a theme for their speech. It's also nice if the Table Topics Master can work around your chosen theme.
Contact the following members in advance:
subItems: Speakers: Ask them to fill speech title and details & to get in touch with their evaluator.  Also ask for something interesting which you can use when introducing them (job, family, hobbies, education, why this topic for this audience etc.)
Grammarian: Ask the grammarian to fill the Word of Day at least one week in advance
General Evaluator: Ask this member to contact the Evaluators, Timer, Grammarian and Ah counter.

Timer: Discuss his or her duties. A very important value in our club is that the meeting starts on time and ends on time. During the meeting you want to rely on the timer to time the speeches but also to make sure that the overall meeting keeps within planned timeframe.

Sergeant at Arms: It's your morning. How would you like the room to be set up? Circle? U-shaped with tables and chairs? There's nothing wrong with keeping the room as usual, but certainly nothing wrong with mixing things up a little. Consider the speeches, the audience, etc. when preparing for your role.
Table Topic Master: Ask this member to prepare questions based on the theme.
NOTE: The Toastmaster of the Morning, the Grammarian & the Table Topic Master form the theme-triangle ‚òòÔ∏è. So it's important for all of you co-ordinate with each other ‚òòÔ∏è ‚òòÔ∏è ‚òòÔ∏è

orderedInstructions.mainLine: Keep an eye of meeting agenda/emails for role cancellations.
If a role is unassigned, please contact the VPE.
If a role is already assigned, DO NOT change it. Communicate with the VPE for any changes.
Prepare remarks which can be used to bridge the gaps between program segments. You may never use them, but you should be prepared to avoid possibly awkward periods of silence.
Remember the key for a successful meeting is communication, communication & good communication üòä

paragraphs: Arrive to the venue at least by 8:15 am, to start preparing the white board for the meeting. On the white board you write the Theme of the day, the Word of the day, List of Speakers and Evaluators. (For sample images from past meetings, scroll a little below)
Make sure you have your seat saved so you can easily get up and down and reach the stage without any problems.
Have the agenda order printed out with you. The meeting can go smoothly when you can see what is next, without having to think about it on stage.
(Print the detailed meeting agenda of Ams Early Bird Toastmasters Club at the top corner of the meeting schedule)
Talk with the President before the meeting, to know about time constraints for the Club Business.
Have the agenda order printed out with you. The meeting can go smoothly when you can see what is next, without having to think about it on stage.

Be prepared for last minute changes. You can work of the copy of the agenda to for yourself to work off of. All members with roles, especially the speakers, should contact you directly should something arise and they are unable to attend. It is then your responsibility to find other members to pitch in.

Don‚Äôt panic! Should a speaker let you know at the last minute that they are unable to attend, this is the opportunity to call upon the ‚Äúreserved speaker‚Äù. This role in the agenda is just that, a speaker who is reserved for situations such as this.

Preside with sincerity, energy and decisiveness. Take your audience on a pleasant journey and make them feel that all is going well. Always lead the applause before and after each presenter. After your introduction of another presenter, remain standing near the lectern until you have shaken hands - signifying your hand over of control of the meeting - then be seated.
Start by introducing the theme of the day and speak about it.
Call the General Evaluator to introduce the evaluation team.
This is followed by speeches and then evaluations.
When you introduce every speaker, it is advisable to mention the following:
i) Pathways name ii) Motive of the speech iii) Title of the speech
You can find this in Easy speak and down the agenda from there.

You can use your own style to introduce the speakers. You could contact them in advance to learn what their speech is going to be. Or you can talk about your theme and then weave the speakers and evaluators in between.
Remember to call out for 1 min silence for evaluations!
It is easy to forget the 1 min silence, so it is advisable to write down in the agenda by hand or highlight the item if you printed detailed agenda.
After the speeches and evaluations, call the Table Topic Master of the Day.
After the Table topic Master finishes, you go upon stage again and invite Evaluating Team and the General Evaluator (it is advisable to agree upfront what should be the order)
After evaluations put some closing remarks.
After that you hand the meeting back to the President.
Always remember to shake hands when you go up on stage or call someone on stage.

textbox.heading: Timing
text: Besides introductions and moderating the meeting, one of the most important aspect of being the Toastmaster of the Morning is working within the time we have for our scheduled meetings. That is sufficient time for prepared speeches, evaluations, Table Topics, meeting evaluations and Club Business. If you are presiding over a meeting with Table Topics, it is your responsibility to make sure that the Table Topics are delivered in the right amount of time. Remember, 1 ‚Äì 2 minutes for someone delivering their Table Topics and enough time for the introduction, 1 minute. You work with the Table Topic Master and the Timer to make sure you leave enough time for the general evaluation and Club Business.

textbox.heading: Handing the meeting over to the Presiding Officer
text: Normally, the hand over to the Presiding Officer is the Club President. Before doing that, thank the speakers, the General Evaluator, the Table Topics Master and supporting roles.Close your time as the Toastmaster of the Morning on a high note!
As the Timer you are important in making sure meetings finish on time ‚è≥

paragraphs: Bring your own notebook/paper and make a note of all the crutch words that the member on stage uses.
In the begining of the meeting when the General Evaluator calls the team - introduce your role. This is important for guests.
You will make a report for everyone, up until you are called by the General evaluator to give a report.

While giving a report, you may use different formats such as giving exact count of every word used. E.g: 35 "Ahs", 12 "So", 10 "like". Or you could provide a general report as "more than 30 Ahs, a little ums" etc. It's better to highlight the main crutch word used by the person.

tips: Avoid using words like "You were very bad - you used 56 ahs"

body.heading: How do I add a Word of the Day
text: Adding a word of the day is very simple.
Be aware that you can only pick a word of the day, if you have accepted the role as grammarian. Simply navigate to the meeting in which you will perform the grammarian role.
Once you are on the meeting agenda, you will notice that the word of the day is shown in red link with a plus icon in front of the label.
There are two ways to pick a WOD, either freeform, or by picking a word from a list.

gallery.label: FREEFORM: Click on the plus icon. Now a pop up window will open. and you can fill in the WOD in the text field.
PICK FROM A LIST: Should you need any inspiration, there is also an option to help you select a good word, alternatively you can use other online resources such as thesaurus.com.

tips: As a general rule of thumb, pick a word that is related to the theme of the day. If the theme for the upcoming meeting is e.g. "Freedom" you could pick a word such as "unhampered" or "boundary".
It's good to pick word that people can easily use in multiple ways. It's even better, if it's a word that is not used so often. This way the audience learns something new.

When you introduce your word of the day, explain it's meaning to the audience, along with providing some examples, so they learn how the word is used in different contexts. In some cases it's also a good idea mentioning antonyms and synonyms.

When you introduce your role during the meeting, encourage speakers, evaluators, performing officers, and table topic participants to use the word of the day by highlighting the benefits of thinking about ways to use a new word in a new context and increasing their vocabulary.

name: Table Topics Master
motto: You make us think on our feet!

paragraphs: Find out the Theme or Word of day, to base your questions on
NOTE: The Toastmaster of the Morning, the Grammarian & the Table Topic Master form the theme-triangle ‚òòÔ∏è. So it's important for all of you co-ordinate with each other  ‚òòÔ∏è ‚òòÔ∏è ‚òòÔ∏è
This is not a rule, you may ask any type of question.
Make a list of 8 questions at least! If a speaker cancels out last moment, Table topic session can be extended.
Get the list of members interested in impromptu speaking from the VPE or VPPR.
Get to know the names of guests that come to the meeting.
Introduce yourself and state the rules of Table topic. Rules are:
ulist: You will ask a question and then invite someone to talk
A guest has the right to decline; Member cannot decline
Important to state time limit ‚è≥: Minimum 1 minute, Maximum 2 minutes.

paragraphs: As stated above, please first state the question, pause for a moment and then call a person on stage.
It's advisable to not call a guest for the first question, so that they can see how it goes and warm up.
After every question, check with the Timer if you have time for the next question.
After the last question, thank everyone and hand the word back to the Toastmaster.
Remember to shake hands ü§ù when i) a person comes on stage and ii) when a person finishes.
If you are not seating close to the stage, you may stand on the side, so that hand-overs between you and the speakers are brief.

name: Speaker

NOTE: If you use the projector: it's your responsibility to come early and set it up in the room.
Prepare and practice your speech. Be aware of your speech time limits.
Bonus: if you use the word of the day in your speech.
Congrats on signing up!
If you go beyond the time limit and the Timer rings the bell, please finish off your speech immediately. Do not continue further.
Remember to shake hands ü§ù of the Toastmaster before and after your speech.

name: Meet & Greet
motto: You are the welcoming face of the club this morning

paragraphs: Ask the VPM for the list of expected guests.

instructions.heading: On the morning of the meeting

subItems: Please be at the venue no later than 8.15 the day you are assigned with the "Meet & Greet" role
Since guests start arriving at 8.15, you need to be there to greet them.
Position yourself next to the door behind the table with the badges - this is your spot before the meeting!
Put on your best smile :-)
Greet and shake hands as the members and guests arrive
For the members: help them find their name badges
For first time guests: Make sure to have each guest sign a GDPR form (unless they did that already last time they visited)
Introduce each guest to a member.
Ask the member to sit next to the guest, to make sure no guest will sit alone, and to balance the distribution of guests in the room a bit.
Please also invite guests to join our club later at Gelderlandplein.
Please leave some seats empty near the door for late comers.
For our records: Please keep track which guests showed up and let me know afterwards.
For our records: Please make it so we get the signed copies of the GDPR forms and hand them to the VPM or the secretary after the meeting.
NOTE: If you are the only Meet & Greet person pass the guests on to another member, not to create a "Traffic Jam" at the door, if there are more of you, agree the split between you.
This is your chance to practice Networking skills.
Ask them why they are here, how did they hear about Amsterdam Early Bird Toastmasters Club, and generally get to know them.
Answer questions about the club and toastmasters.
Explain the agenda and general structure of the meeting.
Do mention to guests to put their phone on silent mode.
Point to VPM / our email address for any questions regarding membership.
